Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Boston Scientific Corp. and its subsidiaries, Guidant LLC, Guidant Sales LLC and Cardiac Pacemakers Inc. (Guidant), have agreed to pay $30 million to settle allegations that, between 2002 and 2005, Guidant knowingly sold defective heart devices to health care facilities that in turn implanted the devices into Medicare patients, the Justice Department announced. Boston Scientific acquired Guidant, a medical device manufacturer, in 2006.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Description: A federal judge fined Boston Scientific Corporation more than $7 million for violating an FTC order that was designed to preserve competition in the medical device market.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Guidant LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Boston Scientific Corporation, was formally convicted and sentenced in St. Paul, Minn., before U.S. District Court Judge Donovan W. Frank for criminal violations relating to its interactions with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Judge Frank sentenced Guidant to pay more than $296 million in criminal fines and forfeiture and also to submit to the supervision of the U.S. Probation Office for three years. The Justice Department brought criminal charges against Guidant for its mishandling of short-circuiting failures of three models of its implantable cardioverter defibrillators: the Ventak Prizm 2 DR (Model 1861) and the Contak Renewal (Models H135 and H155). Guidant's Cardiac Rhythm Management division, which produced the defibrillators, is headquartered in Arden Hills, Minn. The company pleaded guilty to the charges the previous April.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Description: Guidant LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Boston Scientific Corp., agreed to pay the United States $9.25 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations that the company inflated the cost of replacement pacemakers and defibrillators to federal health care programs by knowingly failing to grant warranty credits and rebates to hospitals for pacemakers and defibrillators that were explanted while covered under a product warranty or another credit program.

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

NAICS Translation: 423450: Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php
Contained in data obtained on May 23, 2018 in response to a Freedom of Information Act request.

Private Litigation Case Title: Hochstadt et al v. Boston Scientific Corporation et al
Harzewski v. Guidant Corporation et al

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Guidant Corporation agreed to pay $16.75 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it continued to sell heart defibrillators without disclosing its introduction of a modified version that corrected a potentially fatal defect in the product.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Boston Scientific agreed to pay $74 million to the United States to resolve an ongoing investigation concerning its 1998 distribution and subsequent recall of one of its coronary stent delivery systems.
Info Source: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC AGREES TO PAY $74 MILLION TO RESOLVE ALLEGATIONS THAT IT SHIPPED ADULTERATED, MISBRANDED MEDICAL DEVICES, US Fed News, June 24, 2005 (via Nexis).

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Boston Scientific Corporation agreed to pay $188.6 million to resolve multistate allegations of deceptive marketing of its transvaginal surgical mesh devices to patients.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: In its 10-K filing for 2018, Boston Scientific reported a $683 million decrease in its legal accrual due to settlement payments relating to multi-district product liability litigation concerning its transvaginal surgical mesh products; in its 10-K for 2019, it reported a $232 million decrease for the same reason. The settlement amounts were not disclosed in court documents.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Boston Scientific Corp. Pelvic Repair System Products Liability Litigation
